journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: A new high dimension nonlinear dynamics simulation model for four-wheel-steering vehicle

article-meta.aff: School of Mechanical and Electric Engineering, Northwest A and F University, Yangling, Shaanxi, China

author-notes.corresp: Yuling Song, School of Mechanical and Electric Engineering, Northwest A and F University, Yangling, Shaanxi 712100, China. Email: syl791026@126.com

abstract.p: A novel method and process that produce the multiple-degrees-of-freedom dynamic model of four-wheel-steering vehicle is proposed for dynamic prediction. It can avoid disadvantages of half-baked expression by simple linear dynamic model through thinking about nonlinear specialty of tire and applying two-dimensional LuGre tire friction model. The complexity caused by the unit of suspension which has absolute value elasticity and subsection linear damper is solved during modeling. Based on control law of turning angle, nonlinear dynamic characteristic of four-wheel-steering vehicle is calculated under the condition of small disturbance. The experiment supports the model and confirms a series of simulation results by Matlab 7.0.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: After a four-wheel-steering (4WS) sample vehicle is designed and made, lots of dynamic experiments including turning dynamics need to be done in order to test its capability. It is very benefit to predict dynamic behavior of 4WS vehicle before finishing its design through establishing reasonable dynamic model. Nowadays, safety and comfort stimulate the developments of 4WS vehicle because of its agility, small turning radius, higher speed, and little space on road.1,2 In the former study, two- or three-degrees-of-freedom (DOF) model is used which cannot reflect the whole dynamic behavior but can be controlled easily. Magic formula or linear theory is applied to depict the contact forces between tire and ground in many dynamic models.3,4 In fact, contact forces are nonlinear. Modern vehicles require the little impact and vibration and a lot of nonlinear units are used, e.g. magnetorheological damper, unequal curvature spring, etc.5,6 Owing to these influences of nonlinear factors, linear hypothesis is not supported.

Several prior research studies have investigated the technology of vehicle modeling. Many researchers developed different vehicle dynamic models for different scientific destinations. Qin and Mitsuaki7 established a seven-DOF vertical dynamic model of full vehicle and analyzed its bifurcation and chaos phenomenon by numerical method. Kayhan and Rahmi8 advanced an eight-DOF vertical nonlinear dynamic model of full vehicle with active suspension. The main idea was to control seat and suspension by a robust neural network model and improve the comfort. A seven-DOF model was applied to control the semi-active suspension by Fang et al.9 and double-loop control method was proposed. Based on Pareto theory, Nariman-Zadeh et al.10 optimized a five-DOF vehicle model parameters with passive suspension and increased its performance. These models presented above are developed for the vertical dynamic analysis and control of full vehicle and do not reflect the lateral dynamic performance. Jiangyong et al.11 developed an eight-DOF model for improving vehicle handling and lane keeping performance. This model can calculate lateral and yawing accelerators of vehicle for which it is benefit for chassis control. Magic formula is used in this model which is a static friction formula and does not describe transient friction behavior between tire and ground. Mirzaei12 used a two-DOF model to study the dynamic control of vehicle and proposed a new control strategy for minimum usage of external yaw moment. Wang et al.13 advanced a 12-DOF electric vehicle dynamic model including the steering sub-model for independent wheel torque control. In their models, the friction model between tire and ground is assumed to be linear and does not describe nonlinear and transient friction behavior.

The work in this study is concerned with the development of a novel high dimension nonlinear dynamic simulation model for dynamic prediction of 4WS vehicle. ‘LuGre friction model between tire and ground’ interpreted in third section is used to analyze static and transient friction characteristics between tire and ground. This article is organized as follows. In ‘Establishment of full vehicle nonlinear dynamic model’ section, the 14-DOFs nonlinear dynamic model of 4WS vehicle is presented. The friction expressed by LuGre model is described in ‘LuGre friction model between tire and ground’ section. ‘Turning angle relation of 4WS vehicle’ section presents turning angle relation of four wheels when 4WS vehicle turning. Then, a ‘Numerical simulation’ is executed and the results are confirmed by an experiment. Final section gives a brief conclusion.

sec.title: Establishment of full vehicle nonlinear dynamic model
sec.p:
The dynamic model of one wheel is expressed in Figure 1. Point contact theory which describes the contact status between tire and ground is used during modeling. The coordinate frame ocwij-xcwijycwijzcwij is fixed on the centroid of the wheel, and the ocwijxcwij axes are parallel to longitudinal direction of the bodywork. The motion frame obwij-xbwijybwijzbwij is connected with tangent point between tire and ground and can rotate around obwijzbwij axes. The angle θij between ocwijxcwij and obwijxbwij axes is the turning angle of the wheel. Subscript i, j represent the position of the wheel, where i = front or rear, j = left or right. Fbwxij, Fbwyij, and Nbwij are the contact forces of tire loaded by the ground and they are described in the motion frame obwij-xbwijybwijzbwij. Fcwxij, Fcwyij and Fcwzij, given by transmission shaft and suspension, are loaded on the centroid of wheel and described in the coordinate frame ocwij-xcwijycwijzcwij. R is the radius of wheel, ωij the angular speed of wheel, Tij the torque loaded by transmission shaft, zcwij the vertical displacement of the wheel’s centroid, and kwij and cΔij the equivalent stiffness and damper of tire, respectively. Figure 1.
Dynamic model of one wheel.
Thus, the coordinate transition formula can be described as follows (1)[xcwijycwijzcwij]=[cosθij-sinθij0sinθijcosθij0001][xbwijybwijzbwij]

Using Lagrange’s method and applying formula (1), the dynamic equation of one wheel in coordinate ocwij-xcwijycwijzcwij is established. It can be given as (2){mijx··cwij+Fcwxij+Fbwxijcosθij-Fbwyijsinθij=0mijy··cwij+Fcwyij+Fbwyijcosθij+Fbwxijsinθij=0mijz··cwij-Fcwzij+Fwij+FΔij+mijg=0Jcwijω·ij-Tij-Fbwxij·R=0 where Fwij and FΔij are individually the vertical elastic force and damping force of the tire. The concrete expression is written as Fwij=kwijsgn(Δij)|Δij|nΔijFΔij=cΔijΔ·ij where nΔij is the nonlinear coefficient of tire, Δij the relative deformation of tire, and Fcwzij the force loaded by suspension. It has the expression as follows Fcwzij=Fδij+FcijFδij=kijsgn(δij)|δij|nδijFcij=cijδ·ijcij={ςijδ·ij>0ξijδ·ij<0 where Fδij is the elastic force, Fcij the damping force, kij, δij, and nδij the individually equivalent stiffness coefficient, relative distortion, and nonlinear coefficient of suspension, cij the suspension’s equivalent damping coefficient, and Sgn (*) the symbolic function.

Figure 2 is the dynamic model of the bodywork and describes the forces loaded on the bodywork. It is assumed that the bodywork is a rigid body with six-DOFs of x,y,z,α,β, and γ. The DOF α,β, and γ are individually the rolling angle, the pitching angle, and the yawing angle. The coordinate system o-xyz is superpositioned with the coordinate system O-XYZ that fixed on the ground and it can rotate around shaft oz. The centroid of bodywork is the point o. The end of suspension is connected with the centroid of wheel and gets the counterforce. Figure 2.
Dynamic model of bodywork.

According to Figure 2, in the reference frame o-xyz, if assuming that the centroid speed of bodywork is vo=[x·,y·,z·]T, then the centroid accelerator of bodywork can be expressed as follows (3)ao=[x··-y·γ·,y··+x·γ·,z··]T

The reference frame ocwij-xcwijycwijzcwij is parallel to the reference frame o-xyz, the centriod accelerator of wheel can be given as (4)acwij=[x··cwijy··cwijz··cwij]=[x··-γ··Ycwij-γ·y·-γ·2Xcwijy··+γ··Xcwij+γ·x·-γ·2YcwijZ··cwij] where Xcwij,Ycwij, and Zcwij are the centroid coordinates of wheel in reference frame o-xyz.

For the coordinate system o-xyz can rotate around shaft oz, the dynamic equation of bodywork with six-DOFs can be written as (5){Jxα··-Jyβ·γ·=∑i=f,r∑j=l,r[Fcwyij(z-Zcwij)] -cosα∑i=f,r∑j=l,r[(Fδij+Fcij)Ycwij]Jyβ··+Jxα·γ·=-∑i=f,r∑j=l,r[Fcwxij(z-Zcwij)] +cosβ∑i=f,r∑j=l,r[(Fδij+Fcij)Xcwij]-∑i=f,r∑j=l,rTijJzγ··=∑i=f,r∑j=l,r(FcwyijXcwij)-∑i=f,r∑j=l,r(FcwxijYcwij)m(x··-y·γ·)=∑i=f,r∑j=l,rFcwxijm(y··+x·γ·)=∑i=f,r∑j=l,rFcwyijmz··=-mg-∑i=f,r∑j=l,r(Fδij+Fcij)

Substituting the frontal two equations of formula (2) into formula (5), the internal forces Fcwxij and Fcwyij can be expurgated; i, j has different expressions, i.e. i=f,r and j=l,r, formula (2) depicts dynamic equations of four wheels actually. A 14-DOF full vehicle dynamic model can be obtained if substituting the back two equations of formula (2) into formula (5). Both Δij and δij can be calculated based on geometrical relation that expressed in Figures 1 and 2; so, Fwij, FΔij, Fδij, and Fcij can be obtained. Fbwxij and Fbwyij can be calculated using the LuGre friction model that depicted in ‘LuGre friction model between tire and ground’ section.

sec.title: LuGre friction model between tire and ground
sec.p: The most important work in modeling is to establish friction model between tire and ground. A case of crabs in dynamic analysis emerges if an inaccurate friction model is applied. Dynamic behavior of 4WS vehicle is decided by nonlinear contact force caused by elastic and plastic distortion of tire. For this reason, many scholars developed a series of models to illuminate this contact phenomenon, e.g. a cubic nonlinear model by Tagawa et al.,14 a nonlinear saturated model advanced by Smith and Starkey,15 and ‘Magic formula’.16 Compared with these friction models that mentioned above, LuGre friction model is developed well because it can describe transient friction behavior.17–19 Khayati et al.20 deal with a high-friction pneumatic actuator positioning technique based on a LuGre friction closed-loop dynamic observer. Using LuGre model, Han et al.21 research on a tracking control problem of a mechanical servo system with nonlinear dynamic friction which contains a directly immeasurable friction state variable and an uncertainty caused by incomplete parameter modeling and its variations. Johan et al.22 proposed the port-Hamiltonian formulation of the LuGre friction which can be used as a building block in the physical modeling of systems with friction. LuGre friction model used in this article can be explained as follows.

Basic theory of LuGre friction model is interpreted by Figure 3. It describes microcosmic interaction of two surfaces which have relative motion. It is assumed that bristles exist on the two surface and the relative deformation η(t) produces frictional force when the bristles touch with each other. Figure 3.
LuGre frictional model.

The frictional force is given as a function of relative deformation η(t), and it can be given as (6)F=μ(η)·N where N is the normal pressure, μ(η) the dynamic frictional function and it is written as μ(η)=σ0η+σ1η·+σ2Vr, σ0 the rubber stiffness, σ1 the rubber damping, σ2 the viscous relative damping, and Vr the relative speed. Generally, σ2=0, so μ(η) can be given as (7)μ(η)=σ0η+σ1η·

In formula (7), relative deformation η satisfies the differential equation22 (8)η·=Vr-σ0|Vr|g(Vr)η where the function g(Vr) can be expressed by22 (9)g(Vr)=μd+(μs-μd)exp(-|Vrvs|)δ where μd is the dynamic friction coefficient, μs the static friction coefficient, vs the Stribeck velocity, and δ the Stribeck exponent.

All that mentioned above is one-dimensional friction problem. Actually, when the 4WS vehicle turning, the frictional force between each tire and ground have two components. They are longitudinal force Fbwxij and lateral force Fbwyij. It is a two-dimensional friction problem. If assuming that each dimension is one-dimensional problem, then in the reference frame obwij-xbwijybwijzbwij, the expression of η·can be given as (10)β·=[η·bwxij-(γ·+θ·ij)ηbwyijη·bwyij+(γ·+θ·ij)ηbwxij]

Substituting equation (10) into equation (8), it can be obtained (11){η·bwxij=Vrbwxij-σ0bwxij|Vrbwij|g(Vrbwij)ηbwxij+(γ·+θ·ij)ηbwyijη·bwyij=Vrbwyij-σ0bwyij|Vrbwij|g(Vrbwij)ηbwyij-(γ·+θ·ij)ηbwxij where ηbwxij and ηbwyij are, respectively, tire deformation in the directions of obwijxbwij and obwijybwij. Vrbwxij and Vrbwyij are, respectively, relative speed of contact points between tire and ground, and they are in the directions of obwijxbwij and obwijybwij. σ0bwxij and σ0bwyij are, respectively, rubber stiffness in the directions of obwijxbwij and obwijybwij.
Vrbwxij and Vrbwyij can be written as {Vrbwxij=Rωij-(x·-γ·Ycwij)cosθij-(y·+γ·Xcwij)sinθijVrbwyij=(x·-γ·Ycwij)sinθij-(y·+γ·Xcwij)cosθijVrbwij=Vrbwxij2+Vrbwyij2

By substituting equation (11) into equation (7) and letting σ0=σ0bwxijorσ0bwyijσ1=σ1bwxijorσ1bwyij μ(ηbwxij) and μ(ηbwyij) can be obtained. Therefore, according to equation (6), the frictional force can be expressed by (12){Fbwxij=μ(ηbwxij)(Fwij+FΔij)Fbwyij=μ(ηbwyij)(Fwij+FΔij)

sec.title: Turning angle relation of 4WS vehicle
sec.p:
To a 4WS vehicle, the rear wheels play an important role in steering process. This process is automatically realized by controlling turning angle of rear wheels. A control method is developed in this part. Supposing that turning angles of four wheels can be controlled individually and vehicle turns around a point instantaneously; in this way, turning angle of front-left wheel is regarded as input signal of dynamic system and time delay τ of control system is taken into account. Geometrical relation of turning angles is described in Figure 4. Lij(i = front or rear, j = left or right) represents turning radius of each wheel. Xcwfl, Xcwrl, Ycwfl, and Ycwfr are individually the centroid coordinate of wheels in the reference frame o-xy. Figure 4.
Geometry relation of turning angle. DOF: degrees of freedom.

The turning angle of rear wheel is mainly decided by the vehicle longitudinal velocity and yawing angular speed. If assuming that front-left wheel turning angle θfl is the input signal of dynamic system, rear-left wheel turning angle θrl can be given by the control law (13)θrl=K1[θfl+Asin(ωt)]+K2 where K1=-1K2=Kpx·(t-τ)γ·(t-τ)

Asin(ωt) is the disturbance of ground, A the amplitude, ω the frequency, and τ the time delay of control system. The scale Kp can be given as kp=mσ where σ is the lateral stiffness of tire and m the mass of vehicle.

According to geometrical relation of turning angle that is expressed in Figure 4, we can obtain θfr and θrr θfr=tan-1[tanθfl(Xcwfl-Xcwrl)(tanθfl-tanθrl)(Ycwfl-Ycwfr)+(Xcwfl-Xcwrl)]θrr=tan-1[tanθrl(Xcwfl-Xcwrl)(tanθfl-tanθrl)(Ycwfl-Ycwfr)+(Xcwfl-Xcwrl)]

sec.title: Numerical simulation
sec.p:
In order to expatiate specialty of 4WS vehicle, a simulation flow chart by Matlab 7.0 software is introduced. It can make the simulation process clear and all-purpose. As it is shown in Figure 5, reasonable connection of each block makes simulation process realized. Each block has different functions during simulation. Altering the model program in any block, dynamic behavior of different types of 4WS vehicle can be calculated. As strong nonlinear characteristics of suspension and contact force (LuGre friction model) are used in this study, few methods can get the analytical results. Thus, fourth-order Runge–Kutta approach is applied to solve the multiple-DOFs nonlinear closed-loop dynamic equations with turning angle control law. Figure 5.
Dynamic simulation flow chart of 4WS vehicle. 4WS: four-wheel-steering.

To acquire the dynamic characteristics of 4WS vehicle, lots of numerical analysis are carried out using the parameters in Table 1. Simulation time is defined from 0 to 10 s. Surface of ground is supposed to be planar. Initially, vehicle runs straightly at a constant velocity ωij=90 rad/s from 0 to 3 s and 60 Nm torsion is loaded on four wheels at 2 s. The 4WS vehicle runs at a variable longitudinal velocity which is subjected to a semi-sine turning angle input θfl of front-left wheel from 3 to 8 s. An experimental measurement is carried out according to the simulation condition that is mentioned above. As it is shown in Figure 6, the testing equipments are two angular displacement sensors and a vehicle’s lateral accelerator sensor. The two angular displacement sensors are laid near the centroid of the bodywork and they are vertical with each other. The lateral accelerator sensor is fixed on the centroid of the bodywork. Angular displacement signals measured by angular displacement sensors are dealt with using A/D transform and output through portable vibration measurement equipment. The second derivative signals of angular displacements are calculated by differential method; so, yawing and rolling accelerators are obtained. Lateral accelerator can be directly obtained by the lateral accelerator sensor and output through portable vibration measurement equipment. All the results are dealt with a computer and printed by the printer. Figure 6.
Interpretation of testing course.
Table 1.
Main model parameters.
Parameters Values
x-Axis moment of inertia, Jx (kg m2) 362
y-Axis moment of inertia, Jy (kg m2) 1610
z-Axis moment of inertia, Jz (kg m2) 1785
Mass of bodywork, m (kg) 1135
Stiffness coefficient of tire, kwij (N/m) 200.000
Damper coefficient of tire, cΔij (N s/m) 15
Stiffness coefficient of suspension, kij (N/m) 20.000
Damper coefficient of suspension, ζij (N s/m) 2000
Damper coefficient of suspension, ξij (N s/m) 1500
Nonlinear coefficient of suspension, nδij 1.5
Nonlinear coefficient of tire, nΔij 1.25
Mass of wheel, mij (kg) 28
Wheel moment of inertia, Jcwij (kg m2) 0.1381
Wheel radius, R (m) 0.2
Stribeck exponent, δ 0.5
Stribeck velocity, vs (m/s) 5.5
Longitudinal stiffness coefficient of rubber, σ0bwxij (m−1) 169
Longitudinal damper coefficient of rubber, σ1bwxij (s/m) 1
Lateral stiffness coefficient of rubber, σ0bwyij (m−1) 480
Lateral damper coefficient of rubber, σ1bwyij (s/m) 2
Dynamic frictional coefficient, μd 0.9
Static frictional coefficient, μs 1.3

Figure 7 describes the turning angle input of each wheel. It can be observed from that turning angles of rear wheels are reversed compared with front wheels and turning angles of inboard wheels are bigger than outboard wheels evidently. This phenomenon is mainly decided by the control law (13). If K2<-K1[θfl+Asin(ωt)], then θrl<0, so θrl is subjected to the scale K1. It is very important to design K1 in order to alter the direction of θrl and reduce the accelerator when the vehicle turning. Figure 7.
Turning angle inputs of four wheels.

It can be observed that simulation results in Figure 8 are more nearer to the testing results expressed in Figure 9. Rolling accelerator, α··, yawing accelerator, γ··, and lateral accelerator, y··, are calculated during simulation and taken as the examples for contrastive analysis. From Figures 8(a) and 9(a), it is obtained that variable rule of the two curves is approximately same. Numerical values of longitudinal coordinate have lesser differentiation compared with the two curves. Figure 8.
Numerical results by simulation: (a) rolling accelerator by simulation; (b) yawing accelerator by simulation; and (c) lateral accelerator by simulation.
Figure 9.
Testing results by experiment: (a) rolling accelerator by experiment; (b) yawing accelerator by experiment; and (c) lateral accelerator by experiment.

For the disturbance of ground Asin(ωt) is added to dynamic model, the chattering frequency of curve in Figure 8(a) is a little bigger than that of Figure 9(a). Because the turning angle error and parameter error exist in the dynamic model during simulation, the numerical value obtained by experiment is little bigger than the simulation result between 4 and 6 s. If contrasting Figure 8(b) and (c) with Figure 9(b) and (c), the same feature can be obtained. In brief, the experiment supports the scheme of modeling.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A new dynamic simulation model and flow chart for 4WS vehicle are proposed in this study. Nonlinear factors of suspension and tire are taken into account. LuGre friction model is applied during modeling which depicts the transient frictional behavior and makes the model practical. The simulation results are confirmed by the experiment. The model can be used for identifying control effect of 4WS vehicle and has much benefits for lateral dynamic control. Simultaneously, it is able to be use for analyzing vehicle’s specialty on many conditions including all kinds of turning angle and torsion input, braking peremptorily, decelerating turning, abrupt startup, etc. If letting θrl=0, θrr=0, the model is also fit for 2WS vehicle. The future work is to research turning dynamics of full vehicle on the surface of complex road.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research is supported by Doctor Startup Fund (2011BSJJ016) and Basic Scientific Research Cost (QN2011141) of Northwest A and F University.
